I haven't seen any explicit studies on population size in NEAT
specifically=
, but there have been such studies for genetic algorithms
in general.  I th=
ink Kenneth De Jong's textbook, "Evolutionary
Computation: A Unified Perspe=
ctive" examines it.

However, of course as people have pointed out in NEAT =
it's not just a
question of a healthy population but of healthy species, si=
nce each
species is like its own little population.  In other words, the
sp=
ecies need enough internal diversity to drive their own
explorations.  My o=
wn rule of thumb has been a minimum of 15 members
per species (on average) =
to keep them healthy.  I'm sure 30 is even
safer.  

Another thing to note =
is that the population size you need can vary
wildly by problem and it can =
be surprising.  For pole balancing, it
turns out that you can solve it fast=
est with a minuscule population of
size under 20 total (that's for the whol=
e population!).   That is
because smaller populations are greedier (they co=
ncentrate resources
on a small part of the search space) and apparently pol=
e balancing
benefits greatly from greedy search.  However, that is a specif=
ic
property of pole balancing and I would not expect it to carry over to
mo=
re significant domains.  Surely in some domains having a population
over 10=
00 would lead to the most interesting results, if only you can
afford the l=
uxury of the added computational cost of a large population.

ken
